nameEntry.part: CBE, FRSA, ARAIA, LRIBA, AM, Inst. SE Lon, MSE (Civil)

biogHist.abstract: Florence Taylor was the first woman architect, structural engineer and civil engineer in Australia. For her contribution to architecture and civil engineering, Taylor was appointed an Officer of the British Empire on 8 June 1939 and later a Commander of the British Empire on 10 June 1961.
biogHist.p: Florence Taylor, the eldest of five daughters, of John and Eliza (n√©e Brooks) Parsons imigrated to Australia with her family. She attended Presbyterian Ladies' College (Sydney), and commenced clerical work at an architectural and engineering firm, after her father passed away suddenly.

Realising that draftsmen received a higher scale of pay, she decided to obtain the qualification and enrolled in evening classes at Sydney Technical College - the only female in the class. Between 1900 and 1902 she was apprenticed to the office of Sydney architect Edmund Garton, where she was allocated the less interesting menial tasks. In 1902 she transferred to the office of John Burcham Clamp where she remained until she completed her studies in 1907. In that year her employer Clamp nominated her for associate membership of the New South Wales Institute of Architects. Her membership was granted 13 years later in 1920.

On 3 April 1907, she married George Augustine Taylor, an architect-engineer, whose hobbies included aviation and gliding. Florence Taylor, who shared her husband's interests, became the first woman to attempt a glider flight in Australia, on 5 December 1909. She flew from the Narrabeen sand hills near Sydney, in a guilder built by her husband, to became the first woman to fly a heavier-than-air machine in Australia.

Upon marriage the Taylors established their own company, the Building Publishing Company, a producer of trade and professional journals. Also the Taylors were founding members of the Town Planning Association in New South Wales in 1913.

After her husband's death in 1928, Florence Taylor continued to manage the company until she retired due to ill health in 1961, although she scaled down the company publishing list. Throughout her life Taylor continued to produce town planning schemes.

Oswald Barnett, 1945; Estelle Collman, 1980, 1982; Theresa Garnett, 1964; Irene Greenwood, 1973, 1981, 1984, Date unknown; Elizabeth Griffiths, 1966; Louise Mackay, 1978, 1983; Bessie Mountford, 1963; Jean Mullin; Margaret G. Taylor, 1955; Bill and Rosemary Townsend; and Adrian and Megan Wintle (Locn No.: MLMSS 7206/1/1) 1945-1967; Letters received from her sons, Malcolm and Douglas Booker (Locn No.: MLMSS 7206/1/2) 1961-1991; Letters received from her daughter, Carolyn Norwood (Locn No.: MLMSS 7206/1/3) 1977-1982; Correspondence concerning the nomination for honours of Ruby Sophia Rich-Schalit and Jean Mullin (Locn No.: MLMSS 7206/1/4) 1953-1988; Correspondence with newspaper editors (Locn No.: MLMSS 7206/1/5)
B. H. Douglas, 193- , and Lillie Beirne at Calgary, Canada, 7 July 1940 (Locn No.: MLMSS 7206/2/1) 1945-1948, 1959-1961; Papers concerning, and including the correspondence of, Colin Barclay-Smith (Locn No.: MLMSS 7206/2/2) 1959-1987; Papers concerning Vitamin Supplies Pty Ltd, including correspondence with the company; notices and agenda of Annual General Meeting of shareholders, 1965-1981; and copy of Memorandum and Articles of Association (Locn No.: MLMSS 7206/2/3) 1962; Papers concerning the 2nd National Conference of the Australian Prison After-Care Council, Sydney, 19-23 Feb. 1962 (Locn No.: MLMSS 7206/2/4) 1973-1974; Papers concerning the Australian Crime Prevention, Correction and After-Care Council Seminar, Canberra, 7-8 Mar. 1974 (Locn No.: MLMSS 7206/2/5) 1973, 1980-1989; Papers concerning the Judge Rainbow Memorial Appeal Fund (Locn No.: MLMSS 7206/2/6) 194- , Date unknown; Literary papers, including radio scripts (Locn No.: MLMSS 7206/2/7) 1968-1988; Papers concerning funeral and memorial services (Locn No.: MLMSS 7206/3/1) 1954-1989; General invitations (Locn No.: MLMSS 7206/3/2) 1961-1985; Wedding invitations and order of service (Locn No.: MLMSS 7206/3/3) 193--198-; Newscuttings (Locn No.: MLMSS 7206/3/4) 1920-1990; Notebooks (11) (Locn No.: MLMS 7206/3/5) 1920-1990; Miscellaneous papers, including letter of introduction from R. N.S.W. Division Women's Group Fifth Annual Convention, Sydney, 1 May 1964; Australian Woman's War Charter, 1943; and New Education Fellowship publications (Locn No.: MLMSS 7206/4/2)
